section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: The Things That I LOVE About TREES

section-block.rac_book_title_hed_theme_4_two-lines: The Things That I LOVE About TREES
section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake
section-block.rac_book_summary: In this story, a girl describes her favorite part of trees during each season. From one description to the next, there are many opportunities to talk about ordinal numbers and position words.

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice ordinal numbers up to five by lining up five children in a row and asking questions, such as: Who is the first in line? Who is second? Who is fifth? Repeat.
Sing The Itsy-Bitsy Spider with the children. Point out that rain comes in spring and helps the plants grow, and in the fall it helps wash away the leaves like it does the spider.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Things That I LOVE About TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. Look how the word LOVE is big. Why do you think that is?
Lala loves reading and learning new information. Let’s help her learn about trees and the seasons.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read: What is one change that happens to a tree in a season?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Pause and point out opportunities for children to use ordinal terms to discuss the book and seasons.
On your first read, only read aloud the larger text.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are reading about spring first. What changes happen to trees in spring?
Summer is the second season. How do the flowers on the tree change in summer?
Next, it’s fall. This is the third season of the year. How do the leaves change in fall?
What happens to the leaves after they change color in fall?
Now it’s the fourth season, winter. The leaves aren’t on the trees anymore. Where did they go?
After winter, spring will come again. The branches on the trees start to grow buds again. What will happen next?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What is one change that happens in a season?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to select several children to share their responses with the class.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: In the spring, flower buds grow.
In the winter, the trees are bare.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about the different seasons.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens to trees in the fall?
In the fall, the leaves change c___ (color).
In the fall, the leaves change color.
What is one change that happens in the next season?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Knowing ordinal terms (first, second, third, etc.) allows children to understand and to communicate the orders or placements of people or things. The ordinals “first,” “second,” and “third” are different from the cardinal numbers “one,” “two,” and “three,” so children often need to learn and practice these terms separately.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Use Imagination

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When we use our imaginations, we make pictures in our minds. We can imagine things that are real, like what our house looks like, and we can imagine things that are not real, like a princess riding a dragon. That’s the great thing about using your imagination. You can picture anything you like!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of The Things That I LOVE About TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. We will practice using our imaginations as we read.
Clifford loves to use his imagination to picture what happens in books.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Review ordinal terms with children, and use them to describe seasons. On this second read, include some of the information in the smaller text.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What season is shown first in this book? The blossoms on the tree are buzzing with bees. What do you imagine that sounds like? Can you imagine how the flowers smell? (MB)
The second season in the book is summer. The wind blows the trees. What do you imagine that looks and sounds like? (MB)
What else happens in the summer?
What season is third in this book?
Let’s imagine that the leaves are falling from the tree and we are trying to catch them. Here they come! (MB)
The fourth season is winter. During winter many trees lose their leaves. Imagine standing next to a giant tree on a snowy day. Let’s look up—can you see the sky through the trees? (MB)
There are so many things we can do with trees! Imagine you were going to play with a tree in spring. What would you play first? What would you play second? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Divide children into four groups, one for each season. Encourage each group to use their imaginations to act out various activities you can do in the different seasons. Provide examples such as swimming and eating ice cream in the summer, raking up leaves in the fall, or planting a garden in the spring. Give groups time to decide what they will act out before they share.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the different seasons.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children use their imagination, they practice expressing themselves (both verbally and nonverbally), interacting, reacting, and trying out different roles. Using their imaginations and trying new ways of doing things helps children develop critical thinking skills and encourages creative problem-solving. (www.brighthorizons.com/family-resources)

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice location words by playing a game of Simon Says. For example, Simon says put your hands on top of your head. Put your hands over your eyes, and so on.
Use blocks to teach top and bottom. Stack three to five blocks and ask children to point to the top and bottom blocks. Repeat, ordering the blocks differently each time.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The Things That I LOVE About TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake.
Lala wants to learn more about trees and the seasons!
The leaves change throughout the year. As we read today, I want you to think about this guiding question: What is one way that leaves change in a season?

section.rac_body-text: As you read, pause to ask about the positions of children and objects.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The children are pointing at the top of the tree. What do the leaves in this picture look like?
The children look tiny standing at the bottom of the tree. There are big roots underground, below the bottom of the tree.
How do the leaves change in the summer?
Look at the bird. Is it near the top or the bottom of the tree?
What happens to the leaves in fall? Are they still on the tree? Where do they go?
What happens to the leaves in winter? The girl is at the bottom of the tree looking up at the top. What does she see? How is it different from summer?
Did you think about the guiding question? What is one way that leaves change in a season?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to select several children to share their responses with the class.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The leaves are big in summer.
There are no leaves in winter.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about the different seasons.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the leaves look like in summer?
In summer the leaves are gr___ (green).
In summer the leaves are green.
Which season is your favorite for looking at leaves? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Using spatial language to describe position and location (i.e., near, under, over) helps children better describe their environment and encourages spatial problem-solving. You can support spatial language when asking children to put things away in the classroom by being as specific as possible (“put this on top of the shelf, next to the pens”).

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about the different seasons. Establish what season it is currently, and ask children what changes they noticed during the season. You can play a game of “I Spy” about the seasons. For example, I spy bare trees and snow falling. There are children next to the tree building a snowman. What season is it? Let children guess the season and talk about how they know.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Changing Seasons. It is a poem about different activities we can do in each season.
The Things That I LOVE About TREES and The Changing Seasons both tell about what happens in the four seasons. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Things That I Love... book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do we do during different seasons?
This poem talks about how the seasons change and what we can do in each season. Think about what you like to do in the different seasons.
In the big book, spring comes first. What season is shown first here? What do you remember about the trees in the winter?
What season is shown here? Spring is when people often plant a garden.
Do you remember how the buds opened on the plum tree in the spring?
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: We picnic to the buzz of bees.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What season is shown third? Where are the bees? Where are the blankets?
What season is shown fourth? Do you remember what happens to the trees in the fall? Where do the leaves go?

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to imagine themselves doing an activity in one of the four seasons. They may choose an activity they have never done but would like to try, like skiing in the winter or swimming in the ocean in the summer. Allow children to use found materials as props if needed. Have children share the activity with the group, explaining their activity using the sentence cloze: In the [season], I like to ___ .
Provide a writing prompt about the different seasons, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning about the four seasons helps children understand how time passes and how things change. Observation is an important part of learning about the seasons, including outside exploration and discussion. While outside, children can make note of changes they see and then draw pictures of their observations in science journals.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to talk about what they learned about the seasons. What did they already know about how trees change in the different seasons?
Invite children to act out an outdoor activity that can be done in each season. Have one child act out an activity and challenge the other children to guess what season it is.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book The Things That I LOVE About TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake.
Lala learned a lot from this book. What are some things you learned about seasons?
We have read all about the different seasons. When we read today, think about this question: What happens during your favorite season?
Let’s imagine we are trees during the different seasons. We will change as the seasons change.
Which is the first season in this book? It says that the bees are carrying pollen from flower to flower. Let’s pretend to be buzzing bees flying to a flower!
In spring, trees wake up from winter. Let’s pretend to wake up to warmer weather.
What is the second season in the book? What happens in summer? Let’s open our arms wide like the tree branches!
Which season is third? What happens after the leaves change colors? Let’s shake our extra leaves off in the wind!
Which season is fourth in the book? Let’s shiver in the cold winter weather.
Next, let’s move in the storm. We can thrash our branches too.

section.rac_body-text: Give children a moment to turn and talk about the guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens during your favorite season?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: In the summer, people go swimming.
In the spring, the flowers bloom.
In the winter, there is snow.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about their favorite season. Have them include what happens first, second, and third.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In the winter, there is sn____ (snow).
In the winter, there is snow.
What are some activities you like to do during your favorite season?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help multilingual learners feel more confident by displaying words and phrases in their home languages. This will help them communicate their thoughts and feelings more easily. For math concepts, you can write out and display the number words, as well as some basic position words, in the child’s home language.
